**Short answer**

Free‑trade agreements (FTAs) usually raise the overall size of the economies that sign them, but the benefits are not spread evenly across all workers.  Empirical work finds the following broad patterns:

| Dimension | Typical direction of the effect | What the evidence says | Main caveats |
|-----------|--------------------------------|------------------------|--------------|
| **Employment (total jobs)** | Small net gain (or no change) in the aggregate employment rate; large **sector‑specific shifts** | Most studies find that trade‑induced job creation in export‑oriented and import‑substituting industries is roughly offset by job losses in import‑competing sectors (e.g., Autor, Dorn & Hanson 2013; OECD 2020). | The net effect depends on the size of the country, the openness of its labor market, and the presence of complementary policies (e.g., active labour‑market programmes). |
| **Wages (average)** | Slight rise in **average real wages** in the long run, but **large heterogeneity** | In high‑income countries, low‑skill wages tend to fall or stagnate while high‑skill wages rise (e.g., Autor et al. 2013; IMF 2022). In many middle‑income countries, average wages rise because trade expands the manufacturing sector and raises productivity (World Bank 2019). | The magnitude varies with labor‑market institutions, the skill composition of the workforce, and the degree of “skill‑biased” technological change that accompanies trade. |
| **Wage inequality** | ↑ in most advanced economies; mixed in developing economies | The “skill‑bias” channel—imports of low‑skill‑intensive goods and exports of high‑skill‑intensive goods—has widened the wage gap in the United States, the EU, and Japan (Baldwin 2016). In some fast‑growing Asian economies, the gap has narrowed because trade created many new low‑skill manufacturing jobs (e.g., Vietnam, Bangladesh). | Inequality is also shaped by education, minimum‑wage laws, union coverage, and tax/transfer systems. |
| **Job quality (hours, benefits, security)** | Often **worsens** for workers who move into low‑skill, export‑oriented factories; **improves** for high‑skill, service‑sector jobs | Case studies of NAFTA‑related maquiladoras show longer hours and weaker contracts for low‑skill workers (Klein & Rojas 2021). In contrast, high‑skill service jobs created by FTA‑driven outsourcing often come with better benefits (e.g., IT services in India). | “Job quality” is hard to measure uniformly; outcomes depend on domestic labour‑law enforcement. |
| **Adjustment costs (short‑run unemployment, geographic mobility)** | **Negative** in the first 2–5 years for regions heavily exposed to import competition | Studies using “exposure” measures (e.g., US counties most exposed to Chinese imports) find spikes in unemployment and out‑migration (Autor, Dorn & Hanson 2016). Similar patterns appear in Mexican states after NAFTA (Moran 2019). | The depth of the dip is reduced when governments provide retraining, unemployment insurance, or relocation subsidies. |

Below is a **case‑study style** look at one of the most‑cited examples of NAFTA’s labor‑market impact: **the U.S. “Rust Belt” manufacturing sector (especially the automobile industry) and the adjacent border‑region towns in Michigan, Ohio, and Indiana**.  The same episode is often used as a benchmark for how a large, bilateral free‑trade agreement can reshape jobs and wages in a specific industry and region.

## 1. Background – What NAFTA did

| Element | What the agreement changed (1994‑2020) |
|---------|----------------------------------------|
| **Tariff elimination** | U.S. duties on most Mexican‑made autos, parts, and steel were phased out (complete by 1996).  Mexico eliminated tariffs on U.S. autos and parts at the same time. |
| **Rules of origin** | To qualify for duty‑free treatment a vehicle had to have ≥ 62 % of its value (later 55 %) produced in North America.  This encouraged “cross‑border supply‑chain integration”: many components were made in the U.S., shipped to Mexico for final assembly, then shipped back. |
| **Investment‑protection chapters** | Made it easier for U.S. automakers to set up “knock‑down” plants (CKD) in Mexico and for Mexican firms to invest in the United States. |
| **Labor‑mobility provisions** | NAFTA created a “temporary entry” (TN) visa for certain professionals, but there was **no general provision for low‑skill workers** to move across borders. |

---
